review.title: Logical and Inequality Implications for Reducing the Size and Complexity of Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization Problems
review.abstract: The quadratic unconstrained binary optimization (QUBO) problem arises in diverse optimization applications ranging from Ising spin problems to classical problems in graph theory and binary discrete optimization. The use of preprocessing to transform the graph representing the QUBO problem into a smaller equivalent graph is important for improving solution quality and time for both exact and metaheuristic algorithms and is a step towards mapping large scale QUBO to hardware graphs used in quantum annealing computers. In an earlier paper (Lewis and Glover, 2016) a set of rules was introduced that achieved significant QUBO reductions as verified through computational testing. Here this work is extended with additional rules that provide further reductions that succeed in exactly solving 10% of the benchmark QUBO problems. An algorithm and associated data structures to efficiently implement the entire set of rules is detailed and computational experiments are reported that demonstrate their efficacy.

metadata.title: Logical and Inequality Implications for Reducing the Size and Complexity of Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization Problems

An earlier paper (Lewis and Glover, 2016) introduced a set of rules that achieve significant QUBO reductions as verified by computer tests.Here, this work is expanded with additional rules that allow further reductions that accurately solve 10% of benchmark QUBO problems. sections.heading: 4. Rules for Assigning Values to Pairs of Variables
sections.text: The rules for assigning values to pairs of variables are more complex than the preceding rules and require a more elaborate logic to justify them. We again specify the associated lower limits on M, which return the result specified by each rule, according to the substitutions specified in Section 3.1.4, without the need to justify these limits. However, in this case, it is sufficient to limit M only to the inequality associated with the rule, and the stronger result that dominates the inequality by assigning specific values to xi and xh will apply automatically. We emphasize that the reference to M is not relevant in these cases, since the assignment of specific values to xi and xxi xh removes these variables from further consideration. However, for sensitivity analysis purposes it may be useful to know permissible values for M that can produce the results of these rules.
